Last Edited: July 18, 2023NextIntroduction to TinaCMSProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/index.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Tina Docs","id":"introduction","last_edited":"2023-07-18T15:51:56.737Z","next":"/docs/product-tour"},"excerpt":" Introduction Tina is an open-source, Git-backed headless content management system (CMS) that empowers both developers and content creators to collaborate seamlessly on a single platform. Tina\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nTina is an open-source, Git-backed headless content management system (CMS) that empowers both developers and content creators to collaborate seamlessly on a single platform. Tina enables developers to craft a custom visual editing experience perfectly tailored to their website or application while supporting a broad range of content types such as Markdown, MDX, and JSON.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/zRkeKSZjlyw\" title=\"TinaCMS Demo video\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Advantages of Tina\n\n### Git-based content management\n\n- Tina uses Git to provide a single source of truth for content and code, enhancing collaboration between developers and content editors.\n- Content changes are committed directly to your repository, ensuring version control and content history.\n\n### Real-time visual editing\n\n- Create and edit content directly in the context of your website or application with Tina's real-time visual editor.\n- Customizable content blocks allow content editors to assemble pages and manage content intuitively, similar to using a site builder.\n- The changes made by the editors can be previewed in real-time before publishing, ensuring the quality of the content.\n\n### Control over content\n\n- Tina's open-source model gives you complete control and ownership over your content.\n- Tina's (optional) self-hosted backend gives you piece of mind from vendor lock-in.\n\n### Scalability\n\n- **Performance at Scale:** Tina is designed for large-scale projects. Whether your site has hundreds or tens of thousands of pages, Tina ensures optimal performance.\n- **Powerful Query Capabilities:** With Tina's unique data layer, your Markdown content becomes as flexible and queryable as if it were in a database.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Advantages of Tina](#advantages-of-tina)\n    - [Git-based content management](#git-based-content-management)\n    - [Real-time visual editing](#real-time-visual-editing)\n    - [Control over content](#control-over-content)\n    - [Scalability](#scalability)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your NextData FetchingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/schema.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Content Modeling with TinaCMS","id":"/docs/schema/","next":"/docs/features/data-fetching"},"excerpt":" Introduction The Tina schema defines the shape of your content. Tina uses a \"content-modeling as code\" approach. This has a few benefits compared to modelling through a UI: The schema is\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nThe Tina schema defines the shape of your content. Tina uses a \"content-modeling as code\" approach. This has a few benefits compared to modelling through a UI:\n\n- The schema is version-controlled\n- Mutating the schema is easy, as you can test out changes locally, or in a branch.\n- The developer can extend the schema in interesting ways (custom validation, custom UI fields, etc).\n\nThe content model, and all configuration code is defined in a file called `tina/config.{ts,js,tsx}`.\n\n```ts\n// tina/config.{ts,js,tsx}\nimport { defineConfig } from 'tinacms'\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // ...\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        fields: [\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Title',\n            name: 'title',\n          },\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Post Body',\n            name: 'body',\n            isBody: true,\n          },\n        ],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n})\n```\n\n## Defining \"collections\"\n\nEach item in your `collections` array represents its own entity. In the above example, we defined a `post` collection, and set its path as `content/posts`, which maps to a directory in our site's repository. Each collection contains an array of `fields`, that each have a defined `type`.\n\n```md\n---\ntitle: This is my title\n---\n\nThis is my main post body.\n```\n\n\u003e Note: The `isBody` property is used to output a given field to the markdown body, instead of its frontmatter.\n\nOnce we've defined a collection, we can edit its fields through the Tina UI, or [query its content](/docs/graphql/overview/) using the Tina Content API.\n\n## \"List\" fields\n\nSpecifying `list: true` on _any_ field type will turn that field into an array of items:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  {\n    label: 'Tags',\n    name: 'tags',\n    type: 'string',\n    list: true,\n  },\n]\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/string-list\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n## Limiting values to a set of options\n\nAny _scalar_ field can accept an `options` array, note that in the example below we're using both `options` and `list` properties:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  {\n    label: 'Categories',\n    name: 'categories',\n    type: 'string',\n    list: true,\n    options: [\n      {\n        value: 'movies',\n        label: 'Movies',\n      },\n      {\n        value: 'music',\n        label: 'Music',\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n]\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/string-list-options\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\u003e Omitting `list: true` (or setting it to `false`) would result in a single-select `radio` field.\n\n## Grouping properties as an \"object\"\n\nAn object type takes either a `fields` or `templates` property (just like the `collections` definition). The simplest kind of `object` is one with `fields`:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  {\n    label: 'Testimonial',\n    name: 'testimonial',\n    type: 'object',\n    fields: [\n      {\n        label: 'Author',\n        name: 'author',\n        type: 'string',\n      },\n      {\n        label: 'Role',\n        name: 'role',\n        type: 'string',\n      },\n      {\n        label: 'Quote',\n        name: 'quote',\n        type: 'string',\n        ui: {\n          component: 'textarea',\n        },\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n]\n// ...\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/object\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\nSetting `list: true` would turn the values into an array:\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/object-list-data\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\u003e More complex shapes can be built by using the [`templates`](/docs/reference/types/object/#with-multiple-templates) property. This allows your editors to build out pages using predefined blocks.\n\n## Defining defaults\n\nEvery collection has a `defaultItem` property, which is used to populate the form when creating a new item. This is useful for setting default values for fields, or for adding default content to the markdown body.\n\n### Default item\n\n```js\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // ...\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        defaultItem: () =\u003e {\n          return {\n            // When a new post is created the title field will be set to \"New post\"\n            title: 'New Post',\n          }\n        },\n        fields: [\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Title',\n            name: 'title',\n          },\n        ],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n})\n```\n\n[See the docs](/docs/reference/collections/) for more examples of how to define defaults.\n\n### Default value for objects\n\nTo set default values for objects of fields, use the `defaultItem` property (see [example here](https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/object-list-data)).\n\n### Default value for rich-text\n\nCurrently, when setting a default value for a [rich-text field](/docs/reference/types/rich-text/), you must provide the document Abstract Syntax Tree (AST). See the following example:\n\n```js\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // ...\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        defaultItem: () =\u003e {\n          return {\n            title: 'My New Post',\n            // The body will be populated with \"Default Text\"\n            body: {\n              type: 'root',\n              children: [\n                {\n                  type: 'p',\n                  children: [\n                    {\n                      type: 'text',\n                      text: 'Default Text',\n                    },\n                  ],\n                },\n              ],\n            },\n          }\n        },\n        fields: [\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Title',\n            name: 'title',\n          },\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Post Body',\n            name: 'body',\n            isBody: true,\n          },\n        ],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n})\n```\n\n## Referencing another document\n\nThe `reference` field connects one document to another and only needs to be defined on _one_ side of the relationship. You can specify any number of collections you'd like to connect:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  // ...\n  {\n    label: 'Author',\n    name: 'author',\n    type: 'reference',\n    collections: ['author'], // points to a collection with the name \"author\"\n  },\n]\n//\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/reference\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n## Available data types\n\nEach field in a collection can be of the following `type`:\n\n### _scalar types_\n\n- [string](/docs/reference/types/string/)\n- [datetime](/docs/reference/types/datetime/)\n- [boolean](/docs/reference/types/boolean/)\n- [image](/docs/reference/types/image/)\n- [number](/docs/reference/types/number/)\n\n### _nonscalar types_\n\n- [reference](/docs/reference/types/reference/)\n- [object](/docs/reference/types/object/)\n- [rich-text](/docs/reference/types/rich-text/)\n\n## Video Tutorial\n\nFor those who prefer to learn from video, you can check out a snippet on media from our [\"TinaCMS Deep Dive\"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcgnJDILv4w\u0026list=PLPar4H9PHKVqoCwZy79PHr8-W_vA3lAOB\u0026pp=iAQB) series.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/PcgnJDILv4w?start=554\u0026end=777\" title=\"TinaCMS Deep Dive (Content Modeling)\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Summary\n\n- Your content is modeled in the `tina/config.{ts,js,tsx}` in your repo using `defineConfig`.\n- Your content model contains an array of \"collections\". A \"collection\" maps a content type to a directory in your repo.\n- A \"collection\" contains multiple fields, which can be of multiple scalar or non-scalar data types.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Defining \"collections\"](#defining-collections)\n  - [\"List\" fields](#list-fields)\n  - [Limiting values to a set of options](#limiting-values-to-a-set-of-options)\n  - [Grouping properties as an \"object\"](#grouping-properties-as-an-object)\n  - [Defining defaults](#defining-defaults)\n    - [Default item](#default-item)\n    - [Default value for objects](#default-value-for-objects)\n    - [Default value for rich-text](#default-value-for-rich-text)\n  - [Referencing another document](#referencing-another-document)\n  - [Available data types](#available-data-types)\n    - [_scalar types_](#scalar-types)\n    - [_nonscalar types_](#nonscalar-types)\n  - [Video Last Edited: January 9, 2022NextContent Modeling with TinaCMSProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/using-tina-editor.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"id":"/docs/using-tina-editor/","title":"Using the Tina Editor","last_edited":"2022-01-09T00:00:00.000Z","next":"/docs/schema"},"excerpt":" Tina is very flexible \u0026 extendable, so any Tina site may have a unique experience. As an introduction, we'll cover the out-of-the-box experience that most of our starters implement. Entering the CMS\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\nTina is very flexible \u0026 extendable, so any Tina site may have a unique experience. As an introduction, we'll cover the out-of-the-box experience that most of our starters implement.  \n\n## Entering the CMS\n\nWhen tina is initialized it creates a static build of your site, and a `/admin` route that allows you to edit your site's content. The static build is located at `\u003cPublicFolder\u003e/admin/index.html`.\n\nWhen this page is visited in the browser, the Tina CMS is loaded and the user is prompted to log in.\n\n![Tina Login Page](/img/tina-login.png)\n\nAfter successfully logging in, the user will arrive at the CMS.\n\n## Using the CMS\n\n![Tina Editor Dashboard](/img/tina-dashboard.png)\n\nDepending on how Tina is configured, one or more Collections will appear in the Global Navigation. Clicking on a Collection will take the user to a Document List for that Collection.\n\n![Tina Editor List Page](/img/tina-list-page.png)\n\nThe table here lists all documents for the chosen Collection. This page also allows the user to create a new document or a new folder see below.\n\n![](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1718664908/add-folder-tinacms_c8pxte.png)\\\nCan create folders to manage content.\n\nIf **contextual-editing** has been configured, clicking on a document will navigate the user to that document's preview with the Sidebar open and ready for editing.\n\n![Tina Editor Visual Editing](/img/tina-contextual-editing.png)\n\nHowever, if **contextual-editing** is not configured or simply not available for a particular Collection, clicking on a document will present the user with the basic editor.\n\n![Tina Editor Standard Editing](/img/tina-standard-editing.png)\n\n\u003e Note: You can learn more about how to set up **contextual-editing** for your users [here](/docs/tinacms-context).\n\nOnce saved, the changes to the document will be stored against the files.\n\n## What's Next?\n\nThere's plenty to do to customize your editing experience. We suggest:\n\n* Checking out [our concept docs](/docs/schema/), to learn how Tina powers the starters under the hood\n* Learn how [Tina can be extended](/docs/advanced/extending-tina/) to create new field components\n* Make your site [editable with Tina on production](/docs/tina-cloud/)\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Entering the CMS](#entering-the-cms)\n  - [Using the CMS](#using-the-cms)\n  - [What's PreviousContent Modeling with TinaCMSNextVisual EditingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/features/data-fetching.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"id":"/docs/features/data-fetching","title":"Data Fetching","prev":"/docs/schema","next":"/docs/contextual-editing/overview"},"excerpt":" Introduction With Tina, your content is stored in Git along with your codebase. Tina provides a Content API in front of your repo-based content, so that you can interact with your files as if they're\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nWith Tina, your content is stored in Git along with your codebase. Tina provides a Content API in front of your repo-based content, so that you can interact with your files as if they're in a database.\n\nYou can:\n\n* Query content for a given collection\n* Apply filters, sorting, pagination, etc\n* Query your content based on relational fields.\n\nTo interface with the API, you can use Tina's type-safe client for data-fetching, or manually write custom GraphQL queries and hit the API yourself.\n\n## Making requests with the Tina Client\n\nThe Tina client is the easiest way to fetch your site's content. The client can be configured the `tina/config.\u003cjs|ts\u003e` in the `defineConfig` function.\n\n\u003e Note: token, clientId and branch are **not** used in [local-mode](/docs/tina-cloud/#local-mode). To setup these values for production see [this doc](/docs/tina-cloud/overview)\n\n```js\n// tina/config.{js,ts,tsx}\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema,\n  token: '***',\n  clientId: '***',\n  branch: 'main',\n})\n```\n\nWhen working locally, the client is built with the local url ([http://localhost:4001/graphql](http://localhost:4001/graphql)). When in [production mode](/docs/tina-cloud/#prod-mode), `clientId`, `branch` and `token` are used to query Tina Cloud.\n\nTina client provides a type-safe query builder, that is auto-generated based on your site's schema:\n\n```js\nimport { client } from '../[pathToTina]/tina/__generated__/client'\n\nconst myPost = await client.queries.post({ relativePath: 'HelloWorld.md' })\n\nconsole.log(myPost.data.title)\n```\n\nThe above `client.queries.post` query is not built-in to Tina's API. This is an example of a query based on *your* defined schema, (where you have a \"post\" collection defined).\n\nOn a page that displays a list of posts, you can fetch the posts like so:\n\n```js\nconst postsResponse = await client.queries.postConnection()\nconst posts = postsResponse.data.postConnection.edges.map((post) =\u003e {\n  return { slug: post.node._sys.filename }\n})\n// This would return an array like: [ { slug: 'HelloWorld.md'}, /*...*/ ]\n```\n\n\u003e For more information on manually writing queries for your specific schema, check out our [\"Writing Custom Queries\"](/docs/data-fetching/custom-queries/#writing-inline-queries) docs.\n\n## The Local Filesystem-based Content API\n\nWhen developing locally, it's often beneficial to talk to the content on your local file-system, rather than talk to the hosted content API. Tina provides a CLI tool that lets you run the Content API locally next to your site. This allows all of your content to be made available through the same expressive GraphQL API during development.\n\n\u003e If you setup Tina via `@tinacms/cli init`, or used one of our starters, this should be setup by default. (Read about the CLI [here](/docs/graphql/cli/.)\n\n## Video Tutorial\n\nFor those who prefer to learn from video, you can check out a snippet on \"Data Fetching\" from our [\"TinaCMS Deep Dive\"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcgnJDILv4w\\\u0026list=PLPar4H9PHKVqoCwZy79PHr8-W_vA3lAOB\\\u0026pp=iAQB) series.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/PcgnJDILv4w?start=403\u0026end=534\" title=\"TinaCMS Deep Dive (Data Fetching)\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Summary\n\n* Tina provides a GraphQL API for querying your git-based content.\n* Tina provides a client that allows you to make type-safe requests to the Content API.\n* The client's \"queries\" property is generated based on *your* schema.\n* A local version of the Content API can be used for local development.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Making requests with the Tina Client](#making-requests-with-the-tina-client)\n  - [The Local Filesystem-based Content API](#the-local-filesystem-based-content-api)\n  - [Video Tutorial](#video-tutorial)\n  - [Summary](#summary)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your NextData FetchingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/schema.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Content Modeling with TinaCMS","id":"/docs/schema/","next":"/docs/features/data-fetching"},"excerpt":" Introduction The Tina schema defines the shape of your content. Tina uses a \"content-modeling as code\" approach. This has a few benefits compared to modelling through a UI: The schema is\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nThe Tina schema defines the shape of your content. Tina uses a \"content-modeling as code\" approach. This has a few benefits compared to modelling through a UI:\n\n- The schema is version-controlled\n- Mutating the schema is easy, as you can test out changes locally, or in a branch.\n- The developer can extend the schema in interesting ways (custom validation, custom UI fields, etc).\n\nThe content model, and all configuration code is defined in a file called `tina/config.{ts,js,tsx}`.\n\n```ts\n// tina/config.{ts,js,tsx}\nimport { defineConfig } from 'tinacms'\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // ...\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        fields: [\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Title',\n            name: 'title',\n          },\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Post Body',\n            name: 'body',\n            isBody: true,\n          },\n        ],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n})\n```\n\n## Defining \"collections\"\n\nEach item in your `collections` array represents its own entity. In the above example, we defined a `post` collection, and set its path as `content/posts`, which maps to a directory in our site's repository. Each collection contains an array of `fields`, that each have a defined `type`.\n\n```md\n---\ntitle: This is my title\n---\n\nThis is my main post body.\n```\n\n\u003e Note: The `isBody` property is used to output a given field to the markdown body, instead of its frontmatter.\n\nOnce we've defined a collection, we can edit its fields through the Tina UI, or [query its content](/docs/graphql/overview/) using the Tina Content API.\n\n## \"List\" fields\n\nSpecifying `list: true` on _any_ field type will turn that field into an array of items:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  {\n    label: 'Tags',\n    name: 'tags',\n    type: 'string',\n    list: true,\n  },\n]\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/string-list\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n## Limiting values to a set of options\n\nAny _scalar_ field can accept an `options` array, note that in the example below we're using both `options` and `list` properties:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  {\n    label: 'Categories',\n    name: 'categories',\n    type: 'string',\n    list: true,\n    options: [\n      {\n        value: 'movies',\n        label: 'Movies',\n      },\n      {\n        value: 'music',\n        label: 'Music',\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n]\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/string-list-options\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\u003e Omitting `list: true` (or setting it to `false`) would result in a single-select `radio` field.\n\n## Grouping properties as an \"object\"\n\nAn object type takes either a `fields` or `templates` property (just like the `collections` definition). The simplest kind of `object` is one with `fields`:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  {\n    label: 'Testimonial',\n    name: 'testimonial',\n    type: 'object',\n    fields: [\n      {\n        label: 'Author',\n        name: 'author',\n        type: 'string',\n      },\n      {\n        label: 'Role',\n        name: 'role',\n        type: 'string',\n      },\n      {\n        label: 'Quote',\n        name: 'quote',\n        type: 'string',\n        ui: {\n          component: 'textarea',\n        },\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n]\n// ...\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/object\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\nSetting `list: true` would turn the values into an array:\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/object-list-data\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\u003e More complex shapes can be built by using the [`templates`](/docs/reference/types/object/#with-multiple-templates) property. This allows your editors to build out pages using predefined blocks.\n\n## Defining defaults\n\nEvery collection has a `defaultItem` property, which is used to populate the form when creating a new item. This is useful for setting default values for fields, or for adding default content to the markdown body.\n\n### Default item\n\n```js\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // ...\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        defaultItem: () =\u003e {\n          return {\n            // When a new post is created the title field will be set to \"New post\"\n            title: 'New Post',\n          }\n        },\n        fields: [\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Title',\n            name: 'title',\n          },\n        ],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n})\n```\n\n[See the docs](/docs/reference/collections/) for more examples of how to define defaults.\n\n### Default value for objects\n\nTo set default values for objects of fields, use the `defaultItem` property (see [example here](https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/object-list-data)).\n\n### Default value for rich-text\n\nCurrently, when setting a default value for a [rich-text field](/docs/reference/types/rich-text/), you must provide the document Abstract Syntax Tree (AST). See the following example:\n\n```js\nexport default defineConfig({\n  // ...\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        defaultItem: () =\u003e {\n          return {\n            title: 'My New Post',\n            // The body will be populated with \"Default Text\"\n            body: {\n              type: 'root',\n              children: [\n                {\n                  type: 'p',\n                  children: [\n                    {\n                      type: 'text',\n                      text: 'Default Text',\n                    },\n                  ],\n                },\n              ],\n            },\n          }\n        },\n        fields: [\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Title',\n            name: 'title',\n          },\n          {\n            type: 'string',\n            label: 'Post Body',\n            name: 'body',\n            isBody: true,\n          },\n        ],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n})\n```\n\n## Referencing another document\n\nThe `reference` field connects one document to another and only needs to be defined on _one_ side of the relationship. You can specify any number of collections you'd like to connect:\n\n```js\n// ...\nfields: [\n  // ...\n  {\n    label: 'Author',\n    name: 'author',\n    type: 'reference',\n    collections: ['author'], // points to a collection with the name \"author\"\n  },\n]\n//\n```\n\n\u003ca href=\"https://tina-gql-playground.vercel.app/reference\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSee Example\u003c/a\u003e\n\n## Available data types\n\nEach field in a collection can be of the following `type`:\n\n### _scalar types_\n\n- [string](/docs/reference/types/string/)\n- [datetime](/docs/reference/types/datetime/)\n- [boolean](/docs/reference/types/boolean/)\n- [image](/docs/reference/types/image/)\n- [number](/docs/reference/types/number/)\n\n### _nonscalar types_\n\n- [reference](/docs/reference/types/reference/)\n- [object](/docs/reference/types/object/)\n- [rich-text](/docs/reference/types/rich-text/)\n\n## Video Tutorial\n\nFor those who prefer to learn from video, you can check out a snippet on media from our [\"TinaCMS Deep Dive\"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcgnJDILv4w\u0026list=PLPar4H9PHKVqoCwZy79PHr8-W_vA3lAOB\u0026pp=iAQB) series.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/PcgnJDILv4w?start=554\u0026end=777\" title=\"TinaCMS Deep Dive (Content Modeling)\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Summary\n\n- Your content is modeled in the `tina/config.{ts,js,tsx}` in your repo using `defineConfig`.\n- Your content model contains an array of \"collections\". A \"collection\" maps a content type to a directory in your repo.\n- A \"collection\" contains multiple fields, which can be of multiple scalar or non-scalar data types.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Defining \"collections\"](#defining-collections)\n  - [\"List\" fields](#list-fields)\n  - [Limiting values to a set of item](#default-item)\n    - [Default value for objects](#default-value-for-objects)\n    - [Default value for rich-text](#default-value-for-rich-text)\n  - [Referencing another document](#referencing-another-document)\n  - [Available data types](#available-data-types)\n    - [_scalar types_](#scalar-types)\n    - [_nonscalar types_](#nonscalar-types)\n  - [Video Unless you're using \"visual editing\", the setup is mostly the same regardless of the site's framework. We also have some guides tailored\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nFor the most part, TinaCMS is framework-agnostic. Unless you're using \"visual editing\", the setup is mostly the same regardless of the site's framework.\n\nWe also have some guides tailored for some popular frameworks:\n\n* 👑 **[Next.js](/docs/frameworks/next/overview)**\n* [Astro](/docs/frameworks/astro/)\n* [Hugo](/docs/frameworks/hugo/)\n* [Remix](/docs/frameworks/remix/)\n* [Gatsby](/docs/frameworks/gatsby/)\n* [Jekyll](/docs/frameworks/jekyll/)\n* [11ty](/docs/frameworks/11ty/)\n\n## Coming soon\n\n* Nuxt\n\nNote: popularity can be seen from Google Trends\n\n[https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?q=nuxt%20web,hugo%20web,astro%20web,Gatsby%20web,11ty%20web\\\u0026hl=en](https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?q=nuxt%20web,hugo%20web,astro%20web,Gatsby%20web,11ty%20web\\\u0026hl=en)\n\n## Getting Started\n\nFrom within your site's directory, run:\n\n```bash\n npx @tinacms/cli@latest init\n```\n\nThis will ask you a few setup questions.\n\nWhen prompted for the \"**public assets directory**\", see our [list of frameworks](/docs/integration/frameworks/) for help.\n\n## Updating your build scripts\n\nDepending on your framework, `tina init` may try to update your `package.json` scripts.\n\n```json\n  \"scripts\": {\n    \"dev\": \"tinacms dev -c \\\"next dev\\\"\",\n    \"build\": \"tinacms build \u0026\u0026 next build\",\n    \"start\": \"tinacms build \u0026\u0026 next start\"\n  }\n```\n\nThese should be applied manually if they haven't been set by the CLI.\n\n## Model your content\n\nTo edit your site's content in Tina, you can model your content in the tina/config.ts file.\n\nLearn more about content modelling [here](/docs/schema/)\n\n## Starting TinaCMS\n\nYou can start TinaCMS with:\n\n```bash\nnpx tinacms dev -c \"\u003cyour-dev-process\u003e\"\n```\n\n\u003e `\u003cyour-dev-process\u003e`can be replaced with your site's custom dev command.\n\nWith TinaCMS running, navigate to `http://localhost:3000/admin/index.html`\n\n\u003e ^ The above default port may differ depending on your framework.\n\n\u003e Hint: If you are getting error when running this command please see the [Common Errors](/docs/forestry/common-errors) page.\n\nAt this point, you should be able to see the Tina admin, select a post, save changes, and see the changes persisted to your local markdown files.\n\n![](/img/hugo-tina-admin-screenshot.png)\n\n## Setting up Visual Editing (Optional)\n\nIf you want to power your pages with TinaCMS's API, and you're using a React-based framework, you may be able to leverage TinaCMS's visual editing features.\n\n![block-based-editing-visual](/gif/blocks.gif)\n\nRead more about [data fetching](/docs/features/data-fetching/) and [visual editing](/docs/contextual-editing/overview/).\n\n## Next Steps\n\n* [Check out the content Modeling docs](/docs/schema/)\n* [Learn how to query your content](/docs/features/data-fetching/)\n* [Deploy Your Site](/docs/tina-cloud)\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Coming soon](#coming-soon)\n  - [Getting Started](#getting-started)\n  - [Updating your build 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/product-tour.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"id":"/docs/product-tour/","title":"Introduction to TinaCMS","last_edited":"2022-01-17T15:51:56.737Z","prev":"/docs/index","next":"/docs/setup-overview"},"excerpt":" Here we give a quick 2 minute overview of TinaCMS, and how it fits into your website. If you're instead just looking to quickly get started, jump to our Getting Started Guide. Introduction TinaCMS is\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\nHere we give a quick **2 minute overview of TinaCMS**, and how it fits into your website.\n\n\u003e If you're instead just looking to quickly get started, jump to our [Getting Started Guide](/docs/setup-overview/).\n\n## Introduction\n\nTinaCMS is an open-source Content Management System (CMS) that seamlessly integrates with your Markdown workflow.\n\n![Intro-gif](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1645712511/tina-io/docs/your-blocks.gif)\n\n### Your Website\n\n* With TinaCMS, The developer hosts the site where they like, using whichever framework they choose.\n\n![Website-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874025/tina-io/docs/product-tour/headless_cms1.png)\n\n### Headless CMS\n\n* TinaCMS is \"Headless\", meaning it's decoupled from your website. TinaCMS provides a queryable content API that your website's code consumes.\n\n![Headless-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874025/tina-io/docs/product-tour/headless_cms2.png)\n\n## The CMS Backend\n\n* The TinaCMS backend provides the API for querying your content, offering support for filtering, searching, and pagination.\n\n![Queryable-db-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874024/tina-io/docs/product-tour/queryable_database.png)\n\n### Git-backed Content\n\n* All your content gets backed by git into JSON/Markdown/MDX files\n\n![Git-backed-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874025/tina-io/docs/product-tour/git-backed.png)\n\n### Tina Cloud\n\n* Out of the box, we provide an easy-to-use hosted version of the backend, called Tina Cloud.\n\n![Tina-cloud-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874024/tina-io/docs/product-tour/tina-cloud.png)\n\n### Self-hosted Backend\n\n* For those preferring more control and customization, TinaCMS also allows you to host the backend entirely on your own stack.\n\n![self-hosted-backend-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874024/tina-io/docs/product-tour/self-host-backend.png)\n\n## The CMS Frontend\n\n* TinaCMS provides an intuitive CMS interface for your editors. For sites using React, TinaCMS supports \"Visual Editing\" to allow content editors to see real-time changes.\n\n![your-blocks-gif](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1645712511/tina-io/docs/your-blocks.gif)\n\n### /admin route\n\n* Users interact with the CMS by navigating to the `/admin` page on your site.\n\n![admin-route](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874024/tina-io/docs/product-tour/admin.png)\n\n### Saving\n\n* When users make a change in the CMS, a commit is made back to your Git repository.\n\n![saving-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874024/tina-io/docs/product-tour/git-save.png)\n\n## Integrating TinaCMS into a site\n\nTinaCMS can be setup on your site with `tinacms init`. This installs a few Tina packages, and add some boilerplate\n\n![cli-init-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689819318/tina-io/docs/product-tour/cli-init.png)\n\n### Running TinaCMS Locally\n\n* You also have the flexibility to run TinaCMS locally, sourcing local files instead of interacting with the hosted API. This gives developers an ultra-fast feedback loop.\n\n![local-tina](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1689874024/tina-io/docs/product-tour/local-workflow.png)\n\n### Content Modelling\n\n* Content in TinaCMS is modelled using a `tina/config.ts` file in your project. Through this, you can define \"collections\" that model various content types on your site.\n\n![content-modeling-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1690206543/tina-io/docs/product-tour/content-modelling.png)\n\n### Data-fetching\n\n* TinaCMS provides a GraphQL API, making data-fetching more efficient and powerful.\n\n![graphql-qeury-5-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1690205968/tina-io/docs/product-tour/graphql-query_5.png)\n\n### Client\n\n* Moreover, we also generate a user-friendly client that simplifies the process of querying your content.\n\n![client-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1690206445/tina-io/docs/product-tour/client.png)\n\n### Type-safety\n\n* TinaCMS emphasizes type safety, ensuring your content queries remain error-free and consistent, thus improving code reliability and maintainability.\n\n![type-safety-png](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1690206441/tina-io/docs/product-tour/client-typesafe.png)\n"}},"tocItems":"  - Using the CMS
What's Next?
Last Edited: January 9, 2022NextContent Modeling with TinaCMSProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/using-tina-editor.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"id":"/docs/using-tina-editor/","title":"Using the Tina Editor","last_edited":"2022-01-09T00:00:00.000Z","next":"/docs/schema"},"excerpt":" Tina is very flexible \u0026 extendable, so any Tina site may have a unique experience. As an introduction, we'll cover the out-of-the-box experience that most of our starters implement. Entering the CMS\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\nTina is very flexible \u0026 extendable, so any Tina site may have a unique experience. As an introduction, we'll cover the out-of-the-box experience that most of our starters implement.  \n\n## Entering the CMS\n\nWhen tina is initialized it creates a static build of your site, and a `/admin` route that allows you to edit your site's content. The static build is located at `\u003cPublicFolder\u003e/admin/index.html`.\n\nWhen this page is visited in the browser, the Tina CMS is loaded and the user is prompted to log in.\n\n![Tina Login Page](/img/tina-login.png)\n\nAfter successfully logging in, the user will arrive at the CMS.\n\n## Using the CMS\n\n![Tina Editor Dashboard](/img/tina-dashboard.png)\n\nDepending on how Tina is configured, one or more Collections will appear in the Global Navigation. Clicking on a Collection will take the user to a Document List for that Collection.\n\n![Tina Editor List Page](/img/tina-list-page.png)\n\nThe table here lists all documents for the chosen Collection. This page also allows the user to create a new document or a new folder see below.\n\n![](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1718664908/add-folder-tinacms_c8pxte.png)\\\nCan create folders to manage content.\n\nIf **contextual-editing** has been configured, clicking on a document will navigate the user to that document's preview with the Sidebar open and ready for editing.\n\n![Tina Editor Visual Editing](/img/tina-contextual-editing.png)\n\nHowever, if **contextual-editing** is not configured or simply not available for a particular Collection, clicking on a document will present the user with the basic editor.\n\n![Tina Editor Standard Editing](/img/tina-standard-editing.png)\n\n\u003e Note: You can learn more about how to set up **contextual-editing** for your users [here](/docs/tinacms-context).\n\nOnce saved, the changes to the document will be stored against the files.\n\n## What's Next?\n\nThere's plenty to do to customize your editing experience. We suggest:\n\n* Checking out [our concept docs](/docs/schema/), to learn how Tina powers the starters under the hood\n* Learn how [Tina can be extended](/docs/advanced/extending-tina/) to create new field components\n* Make your site [editable with Tina on production](/docs/tina-cloud/)\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Entering the CMS](#entering-the-cms)\n  - [Using the CMS](#using-the-cms)\n  - [What's Support is provided via our Community Discord Server (Please use the #help channel). Bugs/feature-requests can be filed\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Community support\n\nTinaCMS's front-end is offered as free and open-source. Support is provided via our [Community Discord Server](https://discord.com/invite/zumN63Ybpf) (Please use the #help channel). Bugs/feature-requests can be filed directly in the [TinaCMS GitHub repo](https://github.com/tinacms/tinacms/issues/new/choose).\n\n## Priorized Support\n\nThe Tina team provides prioritized Discord support to individuals on a paid plan. To link your Discord account to your Tina Cloud account, you can click \"verify\" under the `#✅-verify` channel in the [TinaCMS Discord](https://discord.com/invite/zumN63Ybpf). \n\nIf your Tina Cloud email is different than your Discord account, click the 'User another email' button and verify your Tina Cloud email.\n\n![](http://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1693410187/tina-io/Screenshot_2023-08-30_at_12.00.27_PM_pnlyp6.png)\n\n## Enterprise Support\n\nTo learn more about our Enterprise Support Plans, check out our [Enterprise Page](https://tina.io/enterprise/).\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Community support](#community-support)\n  - [Priorized Support](#priorized-support)\n  - [Enterprise In React, this is done by [using the `useTina`](/docs/contextual-editing/react) hook. We are currently working on adding support for other frameworks such as [vue](/docs/contextual-editing/vue).\n\n## Video Tutorial\n\nFor those who prefer to learn from video, you can check out a snippet on Visual Editing from our [\"TinaCMS Deep Dive\"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcgnJDILv4w\\\u0026list=PLPar4H9PHKVqoCwZy79PHr8-W_vA3lAOB\\\u0026pp=iAQB) series.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/PcgnJDILv4w?start=1067\" title=\"TinaCMS Deep Dive (Visual Editing)\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Adding contextual-editing to a page](#adding-contextual-editing-to-a-page)\n  - [Video The useTina hook:
Click to Edit (Experimental)
PreviousVisual EditingNextSetting up a Router for Visual EditingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/contextual-editing/react.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Visual Editing in React","id":"/docs/contextual-editing/react","prev":"/docs/contextual-editing/overview","next":"/docs/contextual-editing/router"},"excerpt":" Visual Editing Requirements: Before a page can be setup with visual editing, it first needs to be using Tina's data-fetching. In react, (or react based frameworks like Next.js) visual editing can be\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n\u003e **Visual Editing Requirements:**\n\u003e\n\u003e - Before a page can be setup with visual editing, it first needs to be using [Tina's data-fetching](/docs/features/data-fetching/).\n\nIn react, (or react based frameworks like Next.js) visual editing can be set up on a page with the `useTina` hook\n\nHere is an example of setting up visual editing, on a NextJS-based site.\n\n```jsx\n// ...\nimport { useTina } from 'tinacms/dist/react'\n\nexport default function Home(props) {\n  // Pass our data through the \"useTina\" hook to make it editable\n  const { data } = useTina({\n    query: props.query,\n    variables: props.variables,\n    data: props.data,\n  })\n\n  // Note how our page title uses \"data\", and not the original \"props.data\".\n  // This ensures that the content will be updated in edit-mode as the user types\n  return \u003ch1\u003e{data.page.title}\u003c/h1\u003e\n}\n\nexport const getStaticProps = async () =\u003e {\n  const pageResponse = await client.queries.page({ relativePath: 'home.mdx' })\n\n  return {\n    props: {\n      data: pageResponse.data,\n      query: pageResponse.query,\n      variables: pageResponse.variables,\n    },\n  }\n}\n```\n\n![usetina-hello-world](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/q_32/v1643294947/tina-io/hello-world.png)\n\n## The `useTina` hook:\n\n`useTina` is used to make a piece of Tina content contextually editable. It is code-split, so that in production, this hook will simply pass through its data value. In edit-mode, it registers an editable form in the sidebar, and contextually updates its value as the user types.\n\n`useTina` takes in a parameter with a few keys:\n\n- `query` and `variables`: These are the same values that you would use for the [backend data-fetching](/docs/features/data-fetching/).\n- `data`: This is the production value that gets passed through to the response unchanged in production.\n\n\u003e Note: Only queries for individual documents can be used with `useTina`\n\nAfter a page is setup with the `useTina` hook, you can add a [router to your collection](/docs/contextual-editing/router) so that you can access contextual-editing from the CMS.\n\n## Click to Edit (Experimental)\n\nTina's \"click to edit\" feature allows editors to select the element they want to edit on the page in order to see it in the sidebar.\n\n\u003cvideo\nclassName=\"video\"\nautoPlay=\"true\"\nloop\nmuted\nplaysInline\u003e\u003csource\nsrc=\"https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/video/upload/q_80,h_584/v1684344056/tina-io/docs/quick-edit-demo.mp4\"\ntype=\"video/webm\"\n/\u003e\u003csource\nsrc=\"https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/video/upload/q_80,h_584/v1684344056/tina-io/docs/quick-edit-demo.mp4\"\ntype=\"video/mp4\"\n/\u003e\n\u003c/video\u003e\n\n\u003e [Try the demo](https://quick-edit-demo.vercel.app/admin#/~)!\n\nIn order for this to work, Tina needs to know what document and field the\nelement is associated with. Tina makes this easy with the `tinaField` helper\nfunction. Using this function, developers can add the appropriate metadata\nto the `[data-tina-field]` attribute.\n\n```jsx\nimport { useTina, tinaField } from 'tinacms/dist/react'\n\nconst Page = (props) =\u003e {\n  const { data } = useTina(props)\n  return (\n    \u003cdiv\u003e\n      \u003ch1 data-tina-field={tinaField(data, 'title')}\u003e{data.title}\u003c/h1\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n  )\n}\n```\n\nNow, when you open the Tina sidebar you'll see editing overlays on any element\nthat's been configured.\n\nFor more information on the tinaField helper, see the [reference docs](/docs/contextual-editing/tinafield)\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [The `useTina` hook:](#the-usetina-hook)\n  - [Click to Edit (Experimental)](#click-to-edit-experimental)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your ProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/forestry/accessing-cms.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Comparing Tina \u0026 Forestry: Accessing the CMS","id":"/docs/forestry/accessing-cms/"},"excerpt":" CMS Hosting One of the main differences between Forestry.io and TinaCMS is how you access the CMS. In Forestry, you access the CMS via our hosted environment (app.forestry.io). In TinaCMS, the CMS\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## CMS Hosting\n\nOne of the main differences between Forestry.io and TinaCMS is how you access the CMS. In Forestry, you access the CMS via our hosted environment (`app.forestry.io`).\n\nIn TinaCMS, the CMS frontend is hosted alongside your site. This pattern is comparable to Forestry's \"remote-admin\" feature, which allows you to access the CMS from your site's URL.\n\nTo set this up, your site's build script will change to something like:\n\n```diff\n- build: hugo\n+ build: tinacms build \u0026\u0026 hugo\n```\n\nThe `tinacms build` step outputs the TinaCMS dashboard SPA in your site's build directory.\n\nOnce TinaCMS is setup, your editors will access the CMS via (`\u003cyour-site-url\u003e/admin`)\n![](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1670430150/tina-io/docs/forestry-migration/accessing-admin.gif)\n\n## Extra flexibility\n\nBy having the CMS-frontend hosted within your site, you have more flexibility/control over your CMS behaviour. Write custom field components, create custom field validations, reuse your schema models, etc.\n\nFor example, here's how you might go about creating a custom \"read-only field\"\n\n```js\n//config.js\n// ...\nconst ReadonlyTextField = wrapFieldsWithMeta(({ input }) =\u003e {\n  return \u003cinput type=\"text\" disabled className={textFieldClasses} {...input} /\u003e\n})\n\nexport default defineSchema({\n  collections: [\n    {\n      label: 'Post',\n      name: 'post',\n      path: 'posts',\n      fields: [\n        {\n          label: 'Title',\n          name: 'title',\n          type: 'string',\n        },\n        {\n          label: 'identifier',\n          name: 'identifier',\n          type: 'string',\n          ui: {\n            component: ReadonlyTextField,\n          },\n        },\n      ],\n    },\n  ],\n})\n```\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [CMS Hosting](#cms-hosting)\n  - [Extra flexibility](#extra-flexibility)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your NextMigrate from ForestryProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/forestry/overview.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Overview","id":"/docs/forestry/overview/","next":"/docs/forestry/migrate"},"excerpt":" Introduction Forestry.io and TinaCMS are both headless content management systems (CMSs) that allow you to manage your content in a centralized location and deliver it to your website or application\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nForestry.io and TinaCMS are both headless content management systems (CMSs) that allow you to manage your content in a centralized location and deliver it to your website or application. However, there are some key differences between the two that you should be aware of.\n\n## Core Differences between Forestry.io and TinaCMS\n\n### Open-source\n\nForestry.io is closed-source, while TinaCMS's front-end is open-source. This means that TinaCMS is far more customizable to have custom fields, plugins, etc.\n\n### Previews\n\nTinaCMS is focused on providing live, in-context editing capabilities, while Forestry.io offers a more traditional approach to content management. This means that with TinaCMS, you can see your changes as you make them, while with Forestry.io, you have to preview your changes in separate window. These previews currently work with React pages, and Vue support is planned for next year.\n\n### Improved Local Workflow\n\nTinaCMS allows devs to iterate more quickly by allowing TinaCMS to be run in dev-mode, locally alongside your site. For example, you can make changes to your content models and fields and see the results immediately, without having to wait for them to be synchronized with a hosted dashboard.\n\nTo read more about some of the specific conceptual difference of TinaCMS vs Forestry, read our [Comparing Forestry \u0026 Tina Concepts doc](/docs/forestry/accessing-cms/)\n\n## Caveats of using TinaCMS\n\n- As mentioned above, TinaCMS's visual editing only supports React-based websites and applications. If your website or application is not built with React, you will still be able to use the TinaCMS standalone editor, but there will be no previews.\n- TinaCMS is a relatively new and rapidly evolving CMS, so there may be some missing Framework-specific features compared to Forestry.\n- Since TinaCMS uses code by configuration, the initial setup process may take a bit more effort compared to Forestry's UI import. This is a tradeoff for the amount of customizability TinaCMS provides.\n\nFor a list of Forestry features that that haven't (yet) made their way to TinaCMS, see our [\"Missing Features Doc\"](/docs/forestry/missing-forestry-features/).\n\nTinaCMS is our V2 CMS, and where our future development efforts will be focused. We're confident TinaCMS will eclipse Forestry's feature-set, and provide a much improved editor experience \u0026 developer experience to teams.\n\nRead on for a step-by-step guide on migrating to TinaCMS from Forestry!\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Core Differences between Forestry.io and TinaCMS](#core-differences-between-forestryio-and-tinacms)\n    - [Open-source](#open-source)\n    - [Previews](#previews)\n    - [Improved Local Workflow](#improved-local-workflow)\n  - [Caveats of using Error: Block template "TemplateName" is not defined for field "FieldName"
Error when getting content in the admin


Error YAMLException: duplicated mapping key
Info: Match ${match} was transformed to ${newMatch}
PreviousMigrate from ForestryNextComparing Tina & Forestry: Accessing the CMSProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/forestry/common-errors.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Common Errors when Migrating","id":"/docs/forestry/common-errors/","prev":"/docs/forestry/migrate","next":"/docs/forestry/accessing-cms"},"excerpt":" Here is a list of the the common things that someone may run into when migrating from Forestry to TinaCMS. Migrating fields with non alphanumeric characters In TinaCMS all fields can only contain\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\nHere is a list of the the common things that someone may run into when migrating from Forestry to TinaCMS.\n\n## Migrating fields with non alphanumeric characters\n\nIn TinaCMS all fields can only contain alphanumeric characters or underscores. While in forestry you could have fields with non alphanumeric characters, such as `my-field-name` or `my field name`.\n\nTinaCMS provides a `nameOverride` property, that allows you to specify how a field with special characters gets output.\n\nE.g:\n\n```js\n// collection fields\n{\n  name: `my_field_name`,\n  nameOverride: `my-field-name`\n}\n```\n\n\u003e The Forestry migration tool (`npx @tinacms/cli init`) should automatically apply nameOverride when importing your templates.\n\n## Migrating Blocks\n\n### \\_template vs template\n\nThe concept of using [blocks as field types in forestry](https://forestry.io/docs/settings/fields/blocks/) is supported in TinaCMS as [providing templates in an object field](/docs/editing/blocks/). During the migration, the migration tool will convert your blocks into templates.\n\n\u003e In TinaCMS, instead of the `template` key we use `_template` by default. The forestry migration tool will handle this automatically by setting the `templateKey` to \"template\" for Forestry sites, but it's something to be aware of.\n\n### Using dashes in block names\n\nIn TinaCMS, it is common for front matter templates to have `-` in the name. TinaCMS doesn't natively support dashes in a field name, however it does support a `nameOverride` property to handle this case.\n\nFor example if you had a front matter template that looked like this.\n\n```yaml\n---\nlabel: landing-page\nfields:\n  - type: blocks\n    name: sections\n    label: Sections\n    template_types:\n      - call-to-action\n      - feature\n      - hero\n```\n\nAnd content that looked like this\n\n```yaml\nsections:\n  - template: call-to-action\n  #   ...\n  - template: feature\n  #   ...\n```\n\nThen in Tina, your block field would look like:\n\n```js\n// ...\n{\n  type: \"object\",\n  list: true,\n  name: \"sections\",\n  label: \"sections\",\n  templateKey: 'template',\n  templates: [\n    {\n      name: 'call-to-action',\n      nameOverride: 'call_to_action',\n      fields: [\n        //...\n      ]\n    },\n    // ...\n  ]\n}\n```\n\nYour output content would continue to look like:\n\n```yaml\n- template: call-to-action\n#   ...\n# this assumes your block has templateKey: 'template' set on your blocks field.\n- template: feature\n#   ...\n```\n\n## Common error message and how to fix them\n\n### Error: Block template \"TemplateName\" is not defined for field \"FieldName\"\n\nIn forestry you could have a block field that had a template that was not defined in the front matter template. In TinaCMS, this is not allowed. You will have to add the template from forestry to to the list of templates in the blocks field and define the fields for that template.\n\n\u003e [See a more in depth video explaining here](https://www.loom.com/share/6dee678048314f7d9afaa6fd8fa59154)\n\n### Error when getting content in the admin\n\n```\n[Error] GetCollection failed: Unable to fetch, errors: Error querying file \u003cFile\u003e from collection pages. Please run \"tinacms audit\" or add the --verbose option for more info\n```\n\n![](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1673619483/tina-io/docs/forestry-migration/Screen-Shot-Error-Messager.png)\n\nThis can happen for many reasons. Some common reasons are because the data you are trying to fetch is\n\n- not in the correct format\n- missing a required field\n- is missing the `_template` key.\n  If you look at the error message in the terminal you should see the exact error that is causing the issue.\n\nFor example, if you are missing `_template` you will see an error like this\n\n```\nError: Unable to determine template for item at hugo/content/about.md, no template name provided for collection with multiple templates\n    at TinaSchema.getCollectionAndTemplateByFullPath (/Users/logananderson-forestry-mac/dev/forestry.io/forestry.io/node_modules/@tinacms/schema-tools/dist/index.js:224:19)\n```\n\nThis can be fixed by adding the `_template` key to the front matter of the file.\n\n```md\n---\n# ...\n_template: my_template\n---\n```\n\n..where \"my_template\" is the name of the template in the collection to which the file belongs.\n\n## Error `YAMLException: duplicated mapping key`\n\nThis happens when you have two keys in the frontmatter of your markdown files that are the same. In forestry, this was allowed but in TinaCMS it is not. You will have to remove one of the keys.\n\nFor example, if you have a file that looks like this\n\n```md\n---\ndate: 2021-01-01\ndate: 2021-01-02\n---\n```\n\nIt will have to be changed to\n\n```md\n---\ndate: 2021-01-02\n---\n```\n\n## Info: Match ${match} was transformed to ${newMatch}\n\nThe match property works a bit differently in TinaCMS than it does in Forestry. In Forestry, the match property is a glob pattern that includes the file extension. In TinaCMS, the match property is a glob pattern that does not include the file extension.\n\nIn TinaCMS the match property is set for each collection and is nested.\n\n```js\n{\n  label: 'Pages',\n  name: 'pages',\n  match: {\n    include: \"{foo,ba}/**/*\"\n  }\n  //..\n}\n```\n\nCheck out the [match property docs](/docs/reference/collections/#matchinclude) for more info.\n\nSince this migration tool is converting from Forestry to TinaCMS, it will automatically convert the match property to the TinaCMS format. It is a good idea to double check that it is matching correctly.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Migrating fields with non alphanumeric characters](#migrating-fields-with-non-alphanumeric-characters)\n  - [Migrating Blocks](#migrating-blocks)\n    - [\\_template vs template](#_template-vs-template)\n    - [Using dashes in block names](#using-dashes-in-block-names)\n  - [Common error message and how to fix them](#common-error-message-and-how-to-fix-them)\n    - [Error: Block template \"TemplateName\" is not defined for field \"FieldName\"](#error-block-template-templatename-is-not-defined-for-field-fieldname)\n    - [Error when getting content in the admin](#error-when-getting-content-in-the-admin)\n  - [Error `YAMLException: duplicated mapping key`](#error-yamlexception-duplicated-mapping-key)\n  - [Info: Match ${match} was transformed to ${newMatch}](#info-match-match-was-transformed-to-newmatch)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your Accessing contextual-editing from the CMS

The router Property


Summary
PreviousVisual EditingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/contextual-editing/router.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Setting up a Router for Visual Editing","id":"/docs/contextual-editing/router","prev":"/docs/contextual-editing/overview"},"excerpt":" Accessing contextual-editing from the CMS At this point, when your editors go to /your-page-url in edit-mode, they will be able to edit content and see those changes reflected on the page, in\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Accessing contextual-editing from the CMS\n\nAt this point, when your editors go to `/your-page-url` in edit-mode, they will be able to edit content and see those changes reflected on the page, in real-time. Next, let's ensure users will be navigated to that same live-editing experience (instead of the basic editor experience) every time they click on a document in the CMS Document List.\n\nTo accomplish this, we will make use of the [`ui.router`](/docs/reference/collections/#definition) property on a collection.\n\n### The `router` Property\n\nThe `router` property is used by the CMS's Document List to navigate to a document's contextual editor rather than the basic editor.\n\n```ts\nrouter: ({ collection: Collection, document: Document }) =\u003e string | undefined\n```\n\nThe `router` property is a function, that is run when a document is clicked within a Document List:\n\n- If `router` returns a `string`, the `string` is used as the document's route rather than the default.\n- If `router` returns `undefined`, the user is navigated to the document's basic editor.\n\nThis is an example using `router`.\n\n```tsx\nconst default defineConfig({\n  schema: {\n    collections: [\n      {\n        name: 'page',\n        label: 'Page',\n        path: 'content/page',\n        format: 'md',\n        ui: {\n          router: ({ document }) =\u003e {\n            // navigate to the home page\n            if (document._sys.filename === 'home') {\n              return '/'\n            }\n            // navigate to the about page\n            if (document._sys.filename === 'about') {\n              return `/about`\n            }\n            return undefined\n          },\n        },\n        fields: [\n          // An array of fields\n        ],\n      },\n      {\n        label: 'Blog Posts',\n        name: 'post',\n        path: 'content/posts',\n        format: 'mdx',\n        ui: {\n          router: ({ document }) =\u003e {\n            // navigate to the post that was clicked\n            return `/post/${document._sys.filename}`\n          },\n        },\n        fields: [\n          // An array of fields\n        ],\n      }\n    ]\n  }\n})\n```\n\nNow when a document is clicked in the CMS we will be re-directed to the page in the site with visual editing.\n\n\u003cvideo\nclassName=\"video\"\nautoPlay=\"true\"\nloop\nmuted\nplaysInline\u003e\u003csource\n          src=\"https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/video/upload/q_100,h_584/e_accelerate:-20/v1655919318/tina-io/docs/RoutMapperVid.webm\"\n          type=\"video/webm\"\n        /\u003e\u003csource\nsrc=\"https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/video/upload/q_80,h_584/e_accelerate:-20/v1655919318/tina-io/docs/RoutMapperVid.mp4\"\ntype=\"video/mp4\"\n/\u003e\n\u003c/video\u003e\n\n## Summary\n\n- A piece of content can be made editable by running it through the `useTina` hook. In production, it returns the original data unchanged. In edit-mode, it returns the live data, which is updated as the user types in the sidebar.\n- Make use of the `router` property to automatically navigate to the contextual-editing experience from the CMS.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Accessing contextual-editing from the CMS](#accessing-contextual-editing-from-the-cms)\n    - [The `router` Property](#the-router-property)\n  - PreviousContent Modeling with TinaCMSNextVisual EditingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/features/data-fetching.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"id":"/docs/features/data-fetching","title":"Data Fetching","prev":"/docs/schema","next":"/docs/contextual-editing/overview"},"excerpt":" Introduction With Tina, your content is stored in Git along with your codebase. Tina provides a Content API in front of your repo-based content, so that you can interact with your files as if they're\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nWith Tina, your content is stored in Git along with your codebase. Tina provides a Content API in front of your repo-based content, so that you can interact with your files as if they're in a database.\n\nYou can:\n\n* Query content for a given collection\n* Apply filters, sorting, pagination, etc\n* Query your content based on relational fields.\n\nTo interface with the API, you can use Tina's type-safe client for data-fetching, or manually write custom GraphQL queries and hit the API yourself.\n\n## Making requests with the Tina Client\n\nThe Tina client is the easiest way to fetch your site's content. The client can be configured the `tina/config.\u003cjs|ts\u003e` in the `defineConfig` function.\n\n\u003e Note: token, clientId and branch are **not** used in [local-mode](/docs/tina-cloud/#local-mode). To setup these values for production see [this doc](/docs/tina-cloud/overview)\n\n```js\n// tina/config.{js,ts,tsx}\nexport default defineConfig({\n  schema,\n  token: '***',\n  clientId: '***',\n  branch: 'main',\n})\n```\n\nWhen working locally, the client is built with the local url ([http://localhost:4001/graphql](http://localhost:4001/graphql)). When in [production mode](/docs/tina-cloud/#prod-mode), `clientId`, `branch` and `token` are used to query Tina Cloud.\n\nTina client provides a type-safe query builder, that is auto-generated based on your site's schema:\n\n```js\nimport { client } from '../[pathToTina]/tina/__generated__/client'\n\nconst myPost = await client.queries.post({ relativePath: 'HelloWorld.md' })\n\nconsole.log(myPost.data.title)\n```\n\nThe above `client.queries.post` query is not built-in to Tina's API. This is an example of a query based on *your* defined schema, (where you have a \"post\" collection defined).\n\nOn a page that displays a list of posts, you can fetch the posts like so:\n\n```js\nconst postsResponse = await client.queries.postConnection()\nconst posts = postsResponse.data.postConnection.edges.map((post) =\u003e {\n  return { slug: post.node._sys.filename }\n})\n// This would return an array like: [ { slug: 'HelloWorld.md'}, /*...*/ ]\n```\n\n\u003e For more information on manually writing queries for your specific schema, check out our [\"Writing Custom Queries\"](/docs/data-fetching/custom-queries/#writing-inline-queries) docs.\n\n## The Local Filesystem-based Content API\n\nWhen developing locally, it's often beneficial to talk to the content on your local file-system, rather than talk to the hosted content API. Tina provides a CLI tool that lets you run the Content API locally next to your site. This allows all of your content to be made available through the same expressive GraphQL API during development.\n\n\u003e If you setup Tina via `@tinacms/cli init`, or used one of our starters, this should be setup by default. (Read about the CLI [here](/docs/graphql/cli/.)\n\n## Video Tutorial\n\nFor those who prefer to learn from video, you can check out a snippet on \"Data Fetching\" from our [\"TinaCMS Deep Dive\"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcgnJDILv4w\\\u0026list=PLPar4H9PHKVqoCwZy79PHr8-W_vA3lAOB\\\u0026pp=iAQB) series.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/PcgnJDILv4w?start=403\u0026end=534\" title=\"TinaCMS Deep Dive (Data Fetching)\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Summary\n\n* Tina provides a GraphQL API for querying your git-based content.\n* Tina provides a client that allows you to make type-safe requests to the Content API.\n* The client's \"queries\" property is generated based on *your* schema.\n* A local version of the Content API can be used for local development.\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Making requests with the Tina Client](#making-requests-with-the-tina-client)\n  - [The Local Filesystem-based Content API](#the-local-filesystem-based-content-api)\n  - [Video Tutorial](#video-tutorial)\n  - [Summary](#summary)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your
