PreviousGetting StartedNextContent Modeling with TinaCMSProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/frameworks/other.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"id":"/docs/frameworks/other","title":"Framework-Agnostic TinaCMS Setup Guide","prev":"/docs/setup-overview","next":"/docs/schema"},"excerpt":" Introduction For the most part, TinaCMS is framework-agnostic. Unless you're using \"visual editing\", the setup is mostly the same regardless of the site's framework. We also have some guides tailored\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nFor the most part, TinaCMS is framework-agnostic. Unless you're using \"visual editing\", the setup is mostly the same regardless of the site's framework.\n\nWe also have some guides tailored for some popular frameworks:\n\n* 👑 **[Next.js](/docs/frameworks/next/overview)**\n* [Astro](/docs/frameworks/astro/)\n* [Hugo](/docs/frameworks/hugo/)\n* [Remix](/docs/frameworks/remix/)\n* [Gatsby](/docs/frameworks/gatsby/)\n* [Jekyll](/docs/frameworks/jekyll/)\n* [11ty](/docs/frameworks/11ty/)\n\n## Coming soon\n\n* Nuxt\n\nNote: popularity can be seen from Google Trends\n\n[https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?q=nuxt%20web,hugo%20web,astro%20web,Gatsby%20web,11ty%20web\\\u0026hl=en](https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?q=nuxt%20web,hugo%20web,astro%20web,Gatsby%20web,11ty%20web\\\u0026hl=en)\n\n## Getting Started\n\nFrom within your site's directory, run:\n\n```bash\n npx @tinacms/cli@latest init\n```\n\nThis will ask you a few setup questions.\n\nWhen prompted for the \"**public assets directory**\", see our [list of frameworks](/docs/integration/frameworks/) for help.\n\n## Updating your build scripts\n\nDepending on your framework, `tina init` may try to update your `package.json` scripts.\n\n```json\n  \"scripts\": {\n    \"dev\": \"tinacms dev -c \\\"next dev\\\"\",\n    \"build\": \"tinacms build \u0026\u0026 next build\",\n    \"start\": \"tinacms build \u0026\u0026 next start\"\n  }\n```\n\nThese should be applied manually if they haven't been set by the CLI.\n\n## Model your content\n\nTo edit your site's content in Tina, you can model your content in the tina/config.ts file.\n\nLearn more about content modelling [here](/docs/schema/)\n\n## Starting TinaCMS\n\nYou can start TinaCMS with:\n\n```bash\nnpx tinacms dev -c \"\u003cyour-dev-process\u003e\"\n```\n\n\u003e `\u003cyour-dev-process\u003e`can be replaced with your site's custom dev command.\n\nWith TinaCMS running, navigate to `http://localhost:3000/admin/index.html`\n\n\u003e ^ The above default port may differ depending on your framework.\n\n\u003e Hint: If you are getting error when running this command please see the [Common Errors](/docs/forestry/common-errors) page.\n\nAt this point, you should be able to see the Tina admin, select a post, save changes, and see the changes persisted to your local markdown files.\n\n![](/img/hugo-tina-admin-screenshot.png)\n\n## Setting up Visual Editing (Optional)\n\nIf you want to power your pages with TinaCMS's API, and you're using a React-based framework, you may be able to leverage TinaCMS's visual editing features.\n\n![block-based-editing-visual](/gif/blocks.gif)\n\nRead more about [data fetching](/docs/features/data-fetching/) and [visual editing](/docs/contextual-editing/overview/).\n\n## Next Steps\n\n* [Check out the content Modeling docs](/docs/schema/)\n* [Learn how to query your content](/docs/features/data-fetching/)\n* [Deploy Your Site](/docs/tina-cloud)\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Coming soon](#coming-soon)\n  - [Getting Started](#getting-started)\n  - [Updating your build PreviousOverviewNextCommon Errors when MigratingProductShowcaseTina CloudIntroductionHow Tina WorksResourcesBlogExamplesRoadmapSupportMediaUse CasesAgenciesDocumentationTeamsJamstack CMSBenefitsMDXMarkdownGitEditorial WorkflowCustomizationSEOComparisonsTinaCMS vs StoryblokTinaCMS vs SanityTinaCMS vs DecapCMSTinaCMS vs ContentfulTinaCMS vs Builder.ioTinaCMS vs StrapiIntegrationsAstroHugoNextJSJekyll GitHub Twitter Discord YouTube LinkedInSecurityOpen Source TelemetryTerms of ServicePrivacy NoticeLicenseSupport© TinaCMS 2019–2024{"props":{"pageProps":{"error":null,"preview":false,"file":{"sha":"","fileRelativePath":"content/docs/forestry/migrate.mdx","data":{"frontmatter":{"title":"Migrate from Forestry","prev":"/docs/forestry/overview","next":"/docs/forestry/common-errors"},"excerpt":" Introduction TinaCMS can be added to your site locally. In this doc, we'll guide you through the local setup, as well as editing on your production site. Getting Started Note: This Tina Migration\u0026hellip;","markdownBody":"\n## Introduction\n\nTinaCMS can be added to your site locally. In this doc, we'll guide you through the local setup, as well as editing on your production site.\n\n\u003cdiv style=\"position:relative;padding-top:56.25%;\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe width=\"560\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\n      style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/OHY8PyeLK1g\" title=\"Migrating from TinaCMS to Forestry\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\u003e\n  \u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Getting Started\n\n\u003e Note: This Tina Migration will change your site's content files. Please back up your site's content before proceeding. This is best done by doing a git commit before proceeding.\n\nFrom within your site's directory, run:\n\n```bash\ngit commit -am \"backup\"\n```\n\nThen, run the migration command:\n\n```bash\n npx @tinacms/cli@latest init\n```\n\nThis will ask you a few questions. When it asks you if you want to migrate your forestry folder please answer `y` for yes.\n\n## Migrating your content\n\nThis will migrate your content from Forestry to TinaCMS. It will create a `tina/config.{ts,js}` that will contain the setup for Tina as well as the schema for your content. However, this migration will not be perfect. You will have to make some changes to your site to get it working with TinaCMS. We will go over these changes in the next section.\n\nThis migration tool takes each section in your `.forestry/settings.yaml` file and turns it into a [TinaCMS collection](http://localhost:3000/docs/schema/#defining-collections). If one or more templates are defined in the section, it will create a [TinaCMS template](docs/reference/templates/) for each front matter template. If only one template is defined it will create a [TinaCMS collection with fields](/docs/reference/collections/#basic-example)\n\nTinaCMS will use the `label` field in the `.forestry/settings.yaml` file as the name of the collection.\n\nTinaCMS handles a few things differently that will cause you to have to make some updates to your site.\n\nHere is a list of the changes that will need to be made to your site:\n\n* You can only have alphanumeric characters or underscores in your field names, templates names, and collection names (**This includes `-`**). You will likely have to update your template names in your content and code. See [this doc](/docs/forestry/common-errors/#migrating-fields-with-non-alphanumeric-characters) for more details.\n* If you are using the \"blocks\" field see [this doc](/docs/forestry/common-errors/#migrating-blocks) for how to migrate your blocks.\n\n## Starting TinaCMS\n\nYou can start TinaCMS with:\n\n```bash\nnpx tinacms dev -c \"\u003cyour-dev-process\u003e\"\n```\n\n\u003e E.g: For a Hugo site, this might look like: `npx tinacms dev -c \"hugo server -D -p 1313\"`\n\nWith TinaCMS running, navigate to `http://localhost:1313/admin`\n\n\u003e ^ The above default port may differ depending on your framework.Hint: If you are getting error when running this command please see the [Common Errors](/docs/forestry/common-errors) page.\n\nAt this point, you should be able to see the Tina admin, select a post, save changes, and see the changes persisted to your local markdown files.\n\n![](/img/hugo-tina-admin-screenshot.png)\n\n## Model your content\n\nIn Forestry, your content models were defined as \"Front Matter Templates\", but in TinaCMS, these are called \"Collections\". These are defined in your `tina/config.js` file. The migration tool will have created a collection for each section in your `.forestry/settings.yaml` file but if you wish to update or change any of these you can do so in the `tina/config.js` file.\n\n```diff\n// ...\nschema: {\n  collections: [\n    {\n-      name: \"post\",\n+      name: \"\u003cname-of-your-model\u003e\",\n-      label: \"Posts\",\n+      label: \"\u003creadable-label-of-your-model\u003e\",\n-      path: \"content/posts\",\n+      path: \"\u003cpath-to-models-directory\u003e\"\n      fields: [\n-     {\n-         type: \"string\",\n-         name: \"title\",\n-         label: \"Title\",\n-         isTitle: true,\n-         required: true,\n-     },\n      {\n         type: \"rich-text\",\n         name: \"body\",\n         label: \"Body\",\n         isBody: true,\n      },\n      // See https://tina.io/docs/schema/\n      // for help modelling your fields\n      ],\n    },\n  ],\n}\n// ...\n```\n\nYou can lean more about content modeling in Tina's [content modeling docs](https://tina.io/docs/schema/).\n\n## Deploy Tina to your site\n\nNext we'll take you from editing with TinaCMS locally to editing in production with your team.\n\n### Step 1) Push your repo to git\n\nPush your repo up to git, along with its new Tina configuration.\n\n### Step 2) Set up a Tina Cloud project\n\nIn production, we'll want to make sure only authorized users can access your Tina admin, and make changes to your content. You can set up a [Tina Cloud project](https://app.tina.io/) to handle this.\nOnce your project is created, you'll also need to generate a read-only-token.\n\nSee our [Tina Cloud docs](https://tina.io/docs/tina-cloud/) for help using Tina Cloud.\n\n### Step 3) Connect the Tina Cloud config to your site\n\nLocally, in your tina/config.js file, set the following config properties:\n\n```diff\nexport default defineConfig({\n// ...\n-    clientId: null,\n+    clientId: \"\u003cyour-tina-cloud-projects-client-id\u003e\",\n-    token: null,\n+    token: \"\u003cyour-tina-cloud-projects-token\u003e\"\n```\n\n\u003e You should apply the token above in an environment variable, instead of hard-coding it.\n\n### Step 4) Configure build commands\n\nTina's build will need to be apart of your site's static generation.\nIf you are using Netlify, this is configured in `app.netlify.com/sites/\u003cyour-site-id\u003e/settings/deploys`\n\nYou should prepend `yarn tinacms build \u0026\u0026 ` or `npx tinacms build \u0026\u0026 ` to your site's build command:\n\n![](https://res.cloudinary.com/forestry-demo/image/upload/v1670337650/tina-io/docs/forestry-migration/Screen_Shot_2022-12-06_at_10.38.10_AM.png)\n\nFor more information on deploying Tina with Netlify, Vercel, or GitHub Pages, [see this doc](/docs/tina-cloud/overview/#deploying-your-site-with-the-tinacms-admin)\n\n### Step 5) Start using Tina!\n\nWith that set, you should be able to push your config to Git and start editing on production at `\u003cyour-site-url\u003e/admin`!\n\n\u003e Tip: If you have Netlify or Vercel previews set up, you can even edit on `\u003cyour-preview-url\u003e/admin`.\n\nAt this point, you'll be able to edit one of your site's files in production. Next we'll guide you through setting up some other Forestry-supported features like media, data files,\n"}},"tocItems":"  - [Introduction](#introduction)\n  - [Getting Started](#getting-started)\n  - [Migrating your content](#migrating-your-content)\n  - [Starting TinaCMS](#starting-tinacms)\n  - [Model your content](#model-your-content)\n  - [Deploy Tina to your site](#deploy-tina-to-your-site)\n    - [Step 1) Push your repo to git](#step-1-push-your-repo-to-git)\n    - [Step 2) Set up a Tina Cloud project](#step-2-set-up-a-tina-cloud-project)\n    - [Step 3) Connect the Tina Cloud config to your site](#step-3-connect-the-tina-cloud-config-to-your-site)\n    - [Step 4) Configure build commands](#step-4-configure-build-commands)\n    - [Step 5) Start using Tina!](#step-5-start-using-tina)\n","docsNav":[{"title":"Introduction","description":"Quickly Setup Tina on your
